title: Renaissance Figures Quiz
description: How well do you remember the brilliant minds of the Renaissance?

questions.question: Which Renaissance artist painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel?
questions.explanation: Michelangelo painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling between 1508 and 1512, one of the most acclaimed artistic achievements in history.

questions.question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
questions.explanation: Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa between approximately 1503 and 1519. It is now housed in the Louvre Museum in Paris.

questions.question: Which Renaissance figure proposed that the Earth revolves around the Sun?
questions.explanation: Nicolaus Copernicus published his heliocentric theory in 1543 in 'On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres.'

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Prince,' a famous treatise on political power?
questions.explanation: Niccolò Machiavelli wrote 'The Prince' in 1513, a groundbreaking work on political strategy and the use of power.

questions.question: Which wealthy Florentine family were the greatest patrons of Renaissance art?
questions.explanation: The Medici family, especially Lorenzo the Magnificent, were the most influential patrons of art and culture during the Italian Renaissance.

questions.question: Which inventor developed the printing press with movable type around 1440?
questions.explanation: Johannes Gutenberg invented the printing press with movable type around 1440, revolutionizing the spread of knowledge in Europe.

questions.question: Who sculpted the famous bronze doors of the Florence Baptistery, called the 'Gates of Paradise'?
questions.explanation: Lorenzo Ghiberti created the bronze doors of the Florence Baptistery (1425-1452), which Michelangelo reportedly called the 'Gates of Paradise.'

questions.question: Which Renaissance playwright wrote 'Romeo and Juliet' and 'Hamlet'?
questions.explanation: William Shakespeare wrote over 37 plays during the English Renaissance, including Romeo and Juliet (c. 1597) and Hamlet (c. 1600).

questions.question: Who was the Renaissance astronomer put on trial by the Inquisition for supporting heliocentrism?
questions.explanation: Galileo Galilei was tried by the Roman Inquisition in 1633 for supporting the Copernican heliocentric model and spent the rest of his life under house arrest.

questions.question: Which Renaissance artist painted 'The School of Athens'?
questions.explanation: Raphael painted 'The School of Athens' between 1509 and 1511 in the Vatican's Apostolic Palace, depicting famous philosophers of antiquity.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Utopia,' describing an ideal society on a fictional island?
questions.explanation: Sir Thomas More published 'Utopia' in 1516, describing an ideal commonwealth on a fictional island. He was later executed by Henry VIII.

questions.question: Which Renaissance artist created the sculpture 'David' standing over 14 feet tall?
questions.explanation: Michelangelo sculpted his famous marble David between 1501 and 1504. It stands 17 feet tall in the Galleria dell'Accademia in Florence.

questions.question: Which Dutch humanist scholar was known as the 'Prince of the Humanists'?
questions.explanation: Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam was the greatest scholar of the Northern Renaissance, known for his wit and his critiques of the Catholic Church.

questions.question: Who is considered the 'Father of the Renaissance' and wrote poetry in Italian rather than Latin?
questions.explanation: Petrarch (Francesco Petrarca) is often called the 'Father of the Renaissance' and 'Father of Humanism' for his devotion to classical learning.

questions.question: Which Renaissance painter was known for his vivid use of color and painted 'Venus of Urbino'?
questions.explanation: Titian (Tiziano Vecelli) was the leading painter of the Venetian school and was famous for his masterful use of color and his painting 'Venus of Urbino' (1538).
